embeds.title: Overload
embeds.description:
Uncommon Skill / 1 :energy_guardian: / The Guardian / Downfall

Draw 4 Cards.
Next turn, draw 2 less cards. (Reduce each of your debuffs by 1.)

messages.content: oh that's the upgrade??? I swear I have never looked twice at this because the base card seems so bad to me that I didn't register that it was part of the self debuff reduction synergy
yeah lol
it's pretty weird as part of that package anyway
you usually want to draw cards _first_ during your turn, but now you want to play temp buff cards, then draw 4 with your even more limited energy?
when this card is good, it's very very good, because 4 draw base is pretty huge. but in my experience, it takes the right deck and support for that to happen

yeah draw that costs energy is always dubious to me since it has an inherent tension with playing the things you draw, and another tension in wanting you to play things (costs energy), play it, then play the things you drew (costs energy) still seems kind of brutal
yeah

in most cases, it just allows you to be extremely picky with the cards you play, accelerating you to your best ones fast, but i have often chosen not to draw cards because my hand is good enough already
^ this is about card draw that costs energy in general, not just overload
this is like, a REALLY high priority upgrade
not only bc it makes the card better
but gives it another use
I'm probably going to continue ignoring this card now but I'm glad I learned this fact about it
you can also mitigate the downside with aggressive stasis usage
this is like reverse turbo
either well-timed to come out on the turn you receive less cards, or with accelerate to force them to come out then
that said, trying to do it without accelerate is a gamble in most cases
This card's nice with energy gen and debuff removals
Can really accelerate
Upgrade is really strange. Just fundamentally changed the card.

Not a card I'm very high on generally. Unupgraded, this is a pretty strange effect, since you just spend an energy playing it, and won't be able to use all of the new cards it just drew. On top of that, you are now only going to draw 4 cards during your next 2 turns as a drawback, which is pretty severe, and can really cost you a lot of chip damage. If you have runic pyramid, you are technically up a card over those 3 turns, and you get access to all the cards faster, which is pretty solid.

The upgrade is massive, making it so that you only get 1 stack of draw reduction, and removing other debuffs, playing nicely with those synergies for guardian, and even reducing debuffs from enemies like weak, vulnerable, and frail. It might be one of the highest impact upgrades in all of downfall, totally changing the functionality of the card and making it miles better. The other key thing about overload+ to keep in mind is how it interacts with having the 4th energy. You have so much more ability to play your cards that debuff yourself before this, and still be able to cast some of the best cards from the draw 4 as well. I am so much more likely to take this card if I already have 4 energy available to me, and especially likely to take it if it's pre-upgraded.

However,outside of those circumstance, this is not a particularly good card in my experience. The drawback is really severe, and I often have multiple cards in my deck that already need/want to be upgraded as guardian. The debuff cards aren't that heavily represented, which means the reduction isn't always relevant, and the other tools that let you reduce debuffs (orange pellets, onyx, resilient plate) are much easier to fit into a general strategy, and are also more powerful cards overall. On top of that, I actually don't think card draw is that useful on guardian, a strong stasis setup (planning, reroute, recover) often mimics the effect of drawing 7+ cards a turn already.

The most common use cases for this are alongside runic pyramid, orange pellets, playing it in a deck that already has several debuffs/debuff removal synergies, having lots of energy generation to use the card draw better, and taking it while heading into late act 3 and act 4 as a way to dig to your scaling faster in those important boss gauntlet fights. I really don't like it in the early game, where it is awful into all 3 act 1 elites, and most hallway fights, and even in act 2, you can rarely afford to spend an energy drawing towards cards that are now harder to cast, especially when you are hampering your next few turns worth of card draw to do so.
wait is it -1 per turn and decreases by 1 per turn?
I thought you just drew less equal to the stack on the next turn and it goes away
it's -2 next turn only
hard to tell whether -1 for 2 turns or -2 for 1 is worse lol
I'd say the 2nd. The first gives you more opportunities to remove the debuff.

overload+ is a top tier guardian card, providing super powerful card draw and utility in debuff removal helping ageist debuffs and keeping your temporary buffs. Overload not + is pretty mid; its still takeable in aggressive guardian decks though just to dig for gem cannon but you will still want  upgrade it as soon as possible still.

out of all of guardian's cards this one has one of the most significant upgrades; having that + makes this card so much stronger way stronger then a normal upgrade usually achieves. The only card that I think has a more important upgrade would be compile packages.
?????? suspension vs. suspension+?????????
that's a lot of question marks
yes exactly
<suspension> just draws like thats good but its not on the same level as this upgrade which makes the card like 3 times as good

embeds.title: Suspension
embeds.description:
Common Skill / 0 :energy_guardian: / The Guardian / Downfall

 (Draw a card.)
Place a card in your hand into **Stasis.**
[ **Socket** ]

messages.content: becoming a cantrip isn't a good upgrade?????
it is a good upgrade its just not the best guardian upgrade
No it just is. Becoming an unconditional non-exhausting cantrip is just the best upgrade.
<compile package> make the card substantially better too. you go from a super strong effect that lets you pick 3 out of 9 cards for free to picking 3 UPGRADED cards

embeds.title: Compile Package
embeds.description:
Rare Skill / 0 :energy_guardian: / The Guardian / Downfall

Choose one of three  (**Upgrade**d) **Packages** to gain.
**Exhaust**.

messages.content: I still think becoming a cantrip is better
draw neutral on a card vs. not draw neutral (especially for an energy neutral card) is just too much
I'm extremely anti-infinite and I actively avoid them. I still think sus+ is just that good, even in non-infinite decks
why? suspension+ is just a consistency boost were as these other upgrades increase the cards powers by so much. Like an upgraded compile package is not a skip ever.
suspension is a better card then overload, but its upgrade spefically is worse in this reguard
I hold the exact opposite opinion. Overload is better than suspension, but sus+ is better than overload +
interesting
I've had many decks that will never take an overload but will gladly accept overload+ . most of the time when I want an suspension its fine whether its upgraded or not
overload is still a really good upgrade, but I will almost never skip a sus+
it is unreliant on your deck, and can also hold a gem. I've had draw positive sus+ with quartz, free 2 temp strength, etc.
iirc they are planning on changing it, lemme check to what though.
will be put a card in stasis, gain 2(5) block
so a buff to sus, nerf to sus+
I'd say exactly what the doctor ordered, but guardian doesn't need more block.
actually speaking about guardian and block, I was gonna leave some feedback but forgot. Time to do that.
guardian and block? that'll be interesting

idk how block fits the theme of the card but I guess theres not much you can do since the card already costs 0 and the only other thing you could make it do is stasis 2 cards (which is not the best idea)
maybe make it start with no socket and upgrade to gain one? the card would be pretty weak though

im not a fan of the change; part of sus's upgrade was supposed to solve the problem of removing 2 cards from your hand while having energy left over. removing infinites means pretty much anything is better but i'd rather have something better than just block
is suspension infinite really a problem though? theres no way its acutally reliable to force one every run
@ sam
like with watcher the reason you can force infinite every run is because the cards you are using are just some of watchers very best cards in general. Suspensions are not killing gremlin nob for you.
at the very least, you don't need it to be forced every run. just enough runs.
and it being common means that's actually pretty damn often
i just avoid them, so i defer to SamLL about how often you can actually make them happen

to make suspension infinite work you need a small deck, probably 2 campfires and a damage source (like a gem, stasis strike, letter opener or something) all before you just die to ironclad because you made a deck that only wins if it goes infinite.
actively going for that plan instead of a normal game route seems really risky; especially when guardian is already really strong in act 1
it's a common card. Getting 2 copies and with the 3 stasis slots holding cards I'm pretty sure you're already infinite, maybe remove 1-2 just to be sure.
released the paragraphs, curious as to what you think.
oop sorry for ping
r e l e a s e   t h e   p a r a g r a p h s
been talking in an irl server where everyone pings so I forgor my B
I personally don't mind it
what happens when you just don't get the second copy and you just die though? Like is it really reasonable to take suspension  instead off a good attack from your first card reward?
so long as I've been online recently, otherwise I might get a notification on my phone when I'm asleep
actually yes, because stasis is surprisingly acceptable in act 1
oh hey
lol

honestly with defensive stance, it's pretty hard to die super fast as guardian, so if I were playing purely for winrate I would say so. Also it's not like it's a horrible card on it's own. Prefers an upgrade, but guardian isn't too upgrade hungry and also visits more camps on average to socket gems.
My bad, I forgot to RTFC, the drawback on overload is -2 during the next turn only. Still a pretty severe drawback that can really punish you next turn
If you have some cards coming out of stasis next turn or are in defensive mode so you won't need to block as much it's not that bad.
between stasis and defensive stance it's pretty tough to get caught off guard as guardian.... hence the name *The Guardian*

Guardian definitely has tools that can help handle the drawback, I just feel like the risk isn't that necessary to take when you consider that a good stasis setup with some accelerate or a solid defensive engine that lets you stall for time can usually accomplish a similar effect (drawing cards) in a very safe fashion.
Yeah bur having additional sources of debuff removal is always nice.

Up to ascension 5 or so, at least, it is about 90% possible to force an infinite every run, and plausible at higher difficulty. I personally assert that this is not actually a problem because I enjoy it and it doesn't seem like anyone is disliking the current situation, so the fact that this is on some level "broken" doesn't seem to be bad for the mod. But, it seems like the mod game designers don't agree necessarily!

I am reminded a bit of a recent article I read about how Diablo 3 is "broken" math wise but exciting and appealing, whereas the newer Diablo 4 has a more solid math core but is unfun and feels like a chore.

I think Kiku is strongly underrating this card, one of the few times I disagree with them. They are correct that the power delta between Overload and Overload+ is high. Even the base card can be quite good for an infinite combo deck because it gets so many cards in hand, which is usually the thing you need most. But, Overload+ is great even if for some idiosyncratic reason you are not comboing off.

The key realization for me in reevaluating it was that it is both card draw _and_ scaling in conjunction with your Rubies and Emeralds. The Guardian loves the extra strength and dexterity, and the ability to draw to your good cards in conjunction with that is versatile and powerful. You can even sometimes end up playing the Overload+ multiple time in the turn to give a good Reprogram impression. 2 fewer cards next turn is really bad; 1 fewer doesn't hurt so much, especially if you have reasonable odds to draw the Overload+ again!


If you are playing a big deck Guardian this is much worse because you are less likely to have your Ruby and Emeralds together with the Overload, and you're not likely to see the Overload again in your hand the next turn. But I don't think that playstyle optimizes Guardian power. Kiku says they often have multiple cards needing upgrades - I fairly regularly end my runs with a fully upgraded deck. (I am usually playing on <=A5 - advice may not all apply at A20.)
yep
it also works really well when combined with other debuff reduction like onyx/resilient plate

that makes sense, I can see why it would work really well at low accessions where you have a lot more time to build the deck and could feasibly beat the act 1 boss without much preparation. I also don't think infinities are necessary a problem, most of the time infinities are quite weak in the base game. The lack of time eater in downfall helps them out a lot though but most of them are still not infinities that you can preform on turn 1 and in from my point of view if the infinite takes until like turn 4 to set up, is it so different then just a normal deck with scaling powers that needs to set up first to win.

I only think infinities are an issue when they become the main strategy for a character. Like with Watcher, the issue with her infinite is that its already made out of her best cards; so if you fail to get the infinite quickly you don't acutally lose the run at all. mean while trying to make something like a heel hook infinite deck on a20 will kill you 95% of the time before it ever happens because you took refused to take good cards in the hopes of making a dream combo.

I think it's largely a playstyle difference going on here. I do often build decks that are 35+ cards, with a large toolbox of options in them to approach the many different challenges that each fight in the run brings. I also play pretty much exclusively on A20, where the presence of ascenders bane, the changed (often faster and more dangerous, some enemies shuffle in more statuses as well) patterns of the enemies, and the smaller room for error (less max HP and starting damaged, less potion slots, worse events, more expensive shops) all encourage the player to add more cards to their deck in the early game to compensate. I also just really enjoy approaching deckbuilding from a toolbox style (my favorite relic as well) where you have the ability to adapt to each fight in different ways. I don't think you can get away with comboing off or forcing combos very effectively at higher ascensions, where gremlin nob, act 1 hallway fights, and especially act 2 hallway fights will punish it significantly.

I do believe that overload+ is pretty solid, but because upgrades are a limited resource (and because it takes time to reach a campfire), I really dislike taking cards that are very weak before their upgrade. I can see how overload regular would be more acceptable in a smaller, more combo focused deck where you can quickly redraw it and neutralize the drawback more effectively. I just don't tend to build that sort of deck very often.
I'm an inbetween guy when it comes to deckbuilding, and I really like overload
I build decks of 25-30 cards
I play mostly a15
and I have found overload does have room to be upgraded quite often
Yeah I vibe in the 25-30 range, on Guardian I play A20 but most of the other characters I vibe at A14
ive found my guardian sits in that range as well
most of the time, my base game chars hit 30-35
so that's kinda interesting
Base game characters need more since deca and donu and time eater give statuses.
i felt in my runs it was just necessity to bringing the deck together enough but maybe that has an influence
donu/deca statuses are not very relevant tbh
more relevant than any downfall boss' statuses (other than 2 of the 5 act 1 bosses)
true true
That makes sense Kiku, as you go up the difficulty there is way more pressure to not be so greedy as I usually am! Enjoying the greedy lifestyle I guess is why I usually play lower
Finding the right balance of difficulty and fun is important. Play what you enjoy. (this post is sponsored by A14 gang)

I would definitely say that A17 and beyond is significantly less fun, though at a certain point you can start to find enjoyment in overcoming the brutal level of challenge and the difficulty of solving the puzzle

Really depends on the person, and especially the character. I play A20 Guardian because I find it fits with my playstyle really well so I get good results, and it still feels challenging but not overbearing.
